Sounds like a challenge to me :) 
There's a gas street light part way down the street which I assume could help to date it (presumably late 1800's). From the shadow and the lack of development on the land in the background, which is apparently across the harbour, I'm guessing that its looking north. Also seems to be a ferry terminal or something similar opposite the end of the street.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] Well sleep is very important, and now that Lorraine has identified it over on the blog - archivesoutside.records.nsw.gov.au/can-you-date-this-phot... - we can put you out of your misery. We wanted to give other folks a go first. It is Bourke Street, Darlinghurst, looking north towards the harbour from near the intersection with Forbes Street. The building that beachomber noted is still there atop the corner cutting, is on the north-east corner of Bourke and Liverpool Streets. The terrace at left is also still there. Google Maps Street View - g.co/maps/c9ne5 I reckon this parallel view, in nearby Forbes Street, was taken on the same day - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4864426495/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thanks for that! I think you are right about the Forbes St photo, which is pre-1893, due to the Fish Market clock tower. Also possibly this one is related - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... . The 1895 interactive map show the building at right to be the rear of the Lunatic Receiving House (1868, James Barnet. Full details SMH 17/11/1868 p.5 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/28422129 ). May or may not be relevant. Hence all the "taxis"?

comment.author: 53922404@N05
comment._content:
beachcomber that's interesting about the Lunatic Receiving House.  I'm trying to work out why the line-up of 2 wheel drays outside that property, or in Bourke Street for that matter. It's not all that handy to the harbour and certain work for the drivers I would have thought, maybe there is a carriers yard/stables in one of the properties or it's a quiet spot for the drivers to wait until their vehicle is needed. 

By the wheel height and dimensions its a line of trades vehicles, heavy, hardwork drays with typically a simple bench seat for the driver and offsider and what nowadays would be called a ute back - a full wooden floored and sided tray with tailgate. Possibly the most common, and useful of horsedrawn vehicles in Australia at the turn of the last century.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/jennysoldcars] Several other photos include lines of these horse'n'carts,  which must have been the 19th century equivalent of the bloke and his ute.  They must have been the only way to get building materials to and from building sites,  and I suppose queued (like taxis) for loads (?).  For example, outside the Customs House when building work was underway - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3794327782/]
